--- Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> At 04:12 19/05/2004, you wrote:
> >No, I don't understand your objective.  Mine is
> clear
> >and simple, to demonstrate that a recurrent neural
> >network can do what animals frequently do, which is
> >remember a sequence of patterns, and then recall
> them
> >in order.  The telephone dialing task is an easy to
> >understand example of this.  (and most people can
> hear
> >a 7 digit number and immediately dial it, showing
> that
> >they remembered it at least briefly.)  Animals do
> it
> >when they remember a route and then find their way
> >back.  I'm not aware that this has been done by any
> >ANN researcher.  I plan to do it after my next two
> >releases, so It's likely to be in the early fall. 
> One
> >of you NEAT people could beat me to it if you got
> >crackin'. :)
> 
> Can we have a bit more detail?
> 
> What will your inputs and outputs be?
> How many symbols and how will you distinguish
> presenting the symbols from 
> retrieving them?
> Will the sequence be temporal or spatial?

The inputs will be a sequence of N random binary
patterns of M bits each.  N & M will be parameters and
we will begin with very small values, then raise them.
 The patterns will be presented sequentially, i.e.,
not simultaneously.  There is at least one additional
input which is a control input to let the net know
that the sequence has ended.  Hence there are M+1
binary inputs.  After the sequence has ended then the
net is expected to repeat it.  Don't forget that a
recurrent ANN can be a signal generator; that's what
is supposed to happen here.  The ANN will generate a
sequence of outputs that is supposed to reproduce the
input sequence.

There are also M+1 outputs.  M of these are supposed
to replicate one of the input patterns during the
"recall" phase.  The other output is a "ready" line
indicating that the output is valid or that the net
has completed its processing.  During the initial
presentation of the sequence the ready output is used
to indicate that the net is ready to accept the next
pattern.  The other outputs are ignored during this
phase.  In the second, or "recall" phase, the ready
output signals that the pattern is ready to be read
from the pattern outputs.

This is very similar to what is done by my 4Play
program, except 4Play did more complex logic than just
repeating memorize values.

=====
Mitchell Timin
